thread.title: School works towards growing orchard at Wainuiomata
thread.title_full: School works towards growing orchard at Wainuiomata

author: Eleanor Wenman
title: School works towards growing orchard at Wainuiomata
text:
School works towards growing orchard at Wainuiomata ELEANOR WENMAN Last updated 11:55, February 27 2017 Supplied 
Charles Watkins (left) and Margaret Angelo help teacher Mary Atua in the gardens at St Claudine Thevenet School. 
It's all green thumbs and fresh fruit for one Wainuiomata school as it looks to plant an orchard alongside its vegetable gardens. 
Teachers at St Claudine Thevenet School have been mixing education and gardening and it's taken off, with the student council working on planting an orchard as well. 
The senior students have already approached nearby nurseries to see if they want to donate trees. 
"It was really a student council idea. One of the goals they set last year was to create a healthy, safe school," principal Sue Jury said. 
READ MORE: 
This year's council would continue on the work and make an orchard a reality. 
However, orchards were expensive so the school also reached out to KidsCan for funding. 
On the KidsCan website she found an "Orchards in Schools" programme, encouraging children to plant and grow fruit trees. 
KidsCan has planted 28 orchards in schools since the programme began, with more than 840 fruit trees growing on school grounds. 
Jury wanted St Claudine Thevenet School to be a part of that so she signed the school up for funding and the school is now on the waiting list. Ad Feedback 
Although she expected it would take some time to get funding, Jury was already looking forward to having fresh fruit and planned on planting basic trees such as apple and pear varieties. 
The vegetable garden was planted last year and the students had been growing fresh vegetables for the school and their families ever since. 
"We have a sharing table - vegetables are put out for students and families to use. For example, we've used pumpkins to make pumpkin soup," Jury said. - Stuff
